unnormalised: First off, keep an eye on changes to the Income Tax Act, 1961. They always tweak things around budget time – expect announcements around Feb-March. You’ll usually see modifications to deductions under sections 80C, 80D etc. People are always trying to figure out how to save tax, isn't it? Like trying to claim HRA when you live in your own house - don't do it, *yaar*.
normalised: First off, keep an eye on changes to the Income Tax Act, one thousand nine hundred and sixty one. They always tweak things around budget time – expect announcements around February to March. You will usually see modifications to deductions under sections eighty C, eighty D etcetera. People are always trying to figure out how to save tax, isn't it? Like trying to claim H-R-A when you live in your own house - do not do it, yaar.

unnormalised: GST is another big one. Rates are constantly being reviewed. Businesses especially need to stay updated with notifications from the CBIC. Remember the whole confusion around the GST rate on textiles last year? Big *halla gulla*! The cutoff for e-invoicing is also something you should keep an eye on. It was lowered to 5 Cr. turnover last year.
normalised: G-S-T is another big one. Rates are constantly being reviewed. Businesses especially need to stay updated with notifications from the C-B-I-C. Remember the whole confusion around the G-S-T rate on textiles last year? Big halla gulla! The cutoff for e-invoicing is also something you should keep an eye on. It was lowered to five crore turnover last year.

unnormalised: Don't forget about direct tax disputes either. The government keeps introducing schemes like the "Vivad Se Vishwas" to settle pending cases. Usually, you have to pay the principal amount, but you can get a waiver on interest and penalties. Check if any of these schemes apply to you. They usually announce these schemes around 1st week of Jan.

unnormalised: Finally, always refer to official sources like the Income Tax Department website and the GST portal for the most up-to-date information. Don't rely solely on news articles or WhatsApp forwards, *okay*? And yeah, consult a CA (Chartered Accountant) or tax lawyer. They can help you navigate this jungle. Hope this helps.
